SENT.plain: Dural arteriovenous fistula (DAVF) is a rare complication of cerebral venous sinus thrombosis (CVST)
DAVFs develop as a result of direct arterial to venous sinus communications evolving in response to an occluded sinus
The authors present a patient with Down's syndrome who developed progressive, uncontrolled seizures and chronic CVST secondary to factor V Leiden deficiency
Brain MRI and computerised tomographic venography revealed a complex secondary DAVF, which once embolised resulted in a dramatic reduction in seizures and improvement in the clinical state
DAVFs should be considered as a potential complication in patients with persistent features of CVST
